unnormalised: ## Return Policies: May God Bless Them (And Maybe Your Wallet)
normalised: ## Return Policies: May God Bless Them (And Maybe Your Wallet)

unnormalised: Let's be honest, folks. We've all been there. You buy that stunning Anarkali suit online from "Desi Diva Designs" because it looks absolutely ravishing on Deepika Padukone. Then, it arrives and… well, let’s just say it looks less Deepika and more…distressed dhurrie on *you*. That's when the fear sets in: "Oh Bhagwan, what's the return policy?!"

unnormalised: Return policies. Those magical, sometimes baffling, pronouncements that stand between you and utter financial ruin when your online shopping spree goes south. They are like the gatekeepers of your hard-earned Rs., guarding them with the vigilance of a Delhi traffic cop at India Gate.
normalised: Return policies. Those magical, sometimes baffling, pronouncements that stand between you and utter financial ruin when your online shopping spree goes south. They are like the gatekeepers of your hard-earned rupees, guarding them with the vigilance of a Delhi traffic cop at India Gate.

unnormalised: Navigating these policies can feel like deciphering ancient Sanskrit texts. Is it a “No Questions Asked” return like your friendly neighbourhood Kirana store in Chandni Chowk (if they even *accept* returns, that is)? Or is it a "We'll need a blood sample, a notarized affidavit, and the written consent of your family deity" kinda situation?

unnormalised: Remember that time I bought a 500 sq ft inflatable swimming pool, thinking my chawl balcony could handle it? (Spoiler alert: It couldn't.) Thank heavens for the 7-day return policy! I wrestled that monstrosity back into its box (with the help of Uncle Sharma and his impressive bicep strength), and got a full refund. Jai Ho!

unnormalised: Seriously though, always, ALWAYS read the fine print. Look for deadlines. Are returns free, or will you have to pay for shipping back to some warehouse in Bangalore? Do they accept returns of *everything*, or are saris, bangles, and pickle jars final sale? Dr. Iyer always tells me to read labels, I guess it applies to E-commerce as well!

unnormalised: So, the next time you're tempted by a "Limited Edition" embroidered jhola bag, remember to check the return policy first. It might save you from having to explain to your mother why you spent Rs. 5000 on something that looks suspiciously like a potato sack with tassels. And trust me, that's a conversation nobody wants to have. Shanti, shanti, shanti.
